column1: A headache is pain or discomfort in the head, scalp, or neck.
The most common type of headache is tension headache.
It is likely caused by tight muscles in your shoulders, neck, scalp, and jaw.
A tension headache: - May be related to stress, depression, anxiety, a head injury, or holding your head and neck in an abnormal position.
A migraine headache involves severe pain.
- Migraines may be triggered by foods, such as chocolate, certain cheeses, or monosodium glutamate (MSG).
Other types of headaches: - Cluster headache is a sharp, very painful headachepainful headache that occurs up to several times a day for months.
- Sinus headache causes pain in the front of the head and face.
- Headache due to a disorder called temporal arteritis.
This is a swollen, inflamed artery that supplies blood to part of the head, temple, and neck area.

In rare cases, a headache can be a sign of something more serious, such as: - Bleeding in the area between the brain and the thin tissue that covers the brain (subarachnoid hemorrhage) - Blood pressure that is very high - Brain infection, such as meningitis or encephalitis, or abscess - Brain tumor - Buildup of fluid inside the skull that leads to brain swelling (hydrocephalus) - Buildup of pressure inside the skull that appears to be, but is not a tumor (pseudomotor cerebri) - Carbon monoxide poisoning - Lack of oxygen during sleep (sleep apnea) - Problems with the blood vessels and bleeding in the brain, such as arteriovenous malformation (AVM), brain aneurysm, or stroke
- Your headache is severe and just in one eye, with redness in that eye.
